body: At first glance I'm guessing this is related to https://github.com/kylebarron/stata_kernel/issues/177, or maybe https://github.com/kylebarron/stata_kernel/issues/162. I don't have time to debug that right now

@SiSeUniBE 	Can you try again with master?
```
pip install git+https://github.com/kylebarron/stata_kernel --upgrade
```

Thanks a lot, @kylebarron, this works!
(Tested with the example above + one longer piece of code)

Sorry, I was too quick with my "it works" statement.
The problem persists in some cases.
I will try to further investigate the issue, but it seems that it happens if the some lines of the code exceeds 80 characters.

Ok thanks. I didn't fix the root problem

> The problem persists in some cases.
> I will try to further investigate the issue, but it seems that it happens
> if the first line of the code exceeds 80 characters.

Ok, after playing around quite a bit, I'm pretty sure now that it is the overall length of the code (after joining lines and removing consecutive whitespace) that matters. It seems the limit is at 496 characters (or bytes).

Thus, the following will work:
```stata
sysuse auto
graph two (scatter price mpg) (lfit price mpg) (qfit price mpg) (lowess price mpg) (lpoly price mpg), xsize(3) ysize(3) ytitle(price) xtitle(`: var label mpg') by(foreign, title("Minimal Example1123456789012341") scale(0.8) iscale(*1.2) ) legend( order( 1 "1234568901234568901234568901234568901234567890123456789" 2 "1234568901234568901234568901234568901234567890123456789" 3 "1234568901234568901234568901234568901234567890123456789" 4 "12345689012345689012345689012345689012345678901234567890"))
```

But not the following (one char longer):

```stata
sysuse auto
graph two (scatter price mpg) (lfit price mpg) (qfit price mpg) (lowess price mpg) (lpoly price mpg), xsize(3) ysize(3) ytitle(price) xtitle(`: var label mpg') by(foreign, title("Minimal Example1123456789012341") scale(0.8) iscale(*1.2) ) legend( order( 1 "1234568901234568901234568901234568901234567890123456789" 2 "1234568901234568901234568901234568901234567890123456789" 3 "1234568901234568901234568901234568901234567890123456789" 4 "123456890123456890123456890123456890123456789012345678900"))
```
(Sorry, it is not really a minimal example, but that is what came out when approaching the limit of 496 chars)

Yes, that's about what I expected. What I changed yesterday removed the extra whitespace in a command, so that was meant to prevent hitting 496 characters. 

I don't know why this happens exactly. I think it has to do with the configuration of [fdpexpect](https://pexpect.readthedocs.io/en/stable/api/fdpexpect.html), which I use to monitor results.

OK, thanks @kylebarron!
It would, of course, be great if this could be fixed in future (as code for stata graphs tends to be long). For the time being, however, users can either ignore the error message popping-up (it does not prevent stata from working) or they can collect the graph specifications and the options in locals and build the command based on them.

FWIW, I am getting this same error on Windows but not on macOS with a very long margins command, so it appears that this error is not only related to graph commands.

For what I can see, it seems that the error happens when sending the command line to stata. It seems that commands that wrap more than 3 lines create the EOF issue reported in the console (the error happens between the second and third wrapped line, so any command longer than 2* linesize+1 create the issue).

The error happens at this line: https://github.com/kylebarron/stata_kernel/blob/master/stata_kernel/stata_session.py#L451
I poked around a little more, and I think I fixed it.
@SiSeUniBE 	@ebardelli 	Could you update to the newest version and try again?

@kylebarron, I tried again with version 1.10.3, with no success.

It seems that the error message slightly changed, but unfortunatly, the result is still the same: no graph displaying with long commands.

The error message is now:

```
Stata
[IPKernelApp] ERROR | Exception in message handler: Traceback (most recent call last): File "C:\Users\sseiler\AppData\Local\Continuum\anaconda3\lib\site-packages\pexpect\expect.py", line 111, in expect_loop incoming = spawn.read_nonblocking(spawn.maxread, timeout) File "C:\Users\sseiler\AppData\Local\Continuum\anaconda3\lib\site-packages\pexpect\fdpexpect.py", line 148, in read_nonblocking return super(fdspawn, self).read_nonblocking(size) File "C:\Users\sseiler\AppData\Local\Continuum\anaconda3\lib\site-packages\pexpect\spawnbase.py", line 176, in read_nonblocking raise EOF('End Of File (EOF). Empty string style platform.') pexpect.exceptions.EOF: End Of File (EOF). Empty string style platform.

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last): File "C:\Users\sseiler\AppData\Local\Continuum\anaconda3\lib\site-packages\ipykernel\kernelbase.py", line 233, in dispatch_shell handler(stream, idents, msg) File "C:\Users\sseiler\AppData\Local\Continuum\anaconda3\lib\site-packages\ipykernel\kernelbase.py", line 399, in execute_request user_expressions, allow_stdin) File "C:\Users\sseiler\AppData\Local\Continuum\anaconda3\lib\site-packages\stata_kernel\kernel.py", line 124, in do_execute text_to_run, md5, text_to_exclude=text_to_exclude) File "C:\Users\sseiler\AppData\Local\Continuum\anaconda3\lib\site-packages\stata_kernel\stata_session.py", line 264, in do rc, res = self.expect(text=text, child=child, md5=md5, **kwargs) File "C:\Users\sseiler\AppData\Local\Continuum\anaconda3\lib\site-packages\stata_kernel\stata_session.py", line 358, in expect code_lines, res = self.clean_log_eol(child, code_lines, res) File "C:\Users\sseiler\AppData\Local\Continuum\anaconda3\lib\site-packages\stata_kernel\stata_session.py", line 452, in clean_log_eol child.expect(r'\r?\n', timeout=5) File "C:\Users\sseiler\AppData\Local\Continuum\anaconda3\lib\site-packages\pexpect\spawnbase.py", line 341, in expect timeout, searchwindowsize, async_) File "C:\Users\sseiler\AppData\Local\Continuum\anaconda3\lib\site-packages\pexpect\spawnbase.py", line 369, in expect_list return exp.expect_loop(timeout) File "C:\Users\sseiler\AppData\Local\Continuum\anaconda3\lib\site-packages\pexpect\expect.py", line 117, in expect_loop return self.eof(e) File "C:\Users\sseiler\AppData\Local\Continuum\anaconda3\lib\site-packages\pexpect\expect.py", line 63, in eof raise EOF(msg) pexpect.exceptions.EOF: End Of File (EOF). Empty string style platform.

<pexpect.fdpexpect.fdspawn object at 0x0000020D6F0CE278> searcher: searcher_re: 0: re.compile('\r?\n')

```
Same here. I am working on a fix on my fork but it still leaves some lines starting with > in the output. I haven't figured out a way to remove them from the output.
I can't tell what's different about the error message. I tried with the example above and that seemed to work fine. Do you have a different example that isn't working?

@ebardelli 	
Regardless of the lines with `>`, did you figure out how to get past the error?
